content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Congratulations! I am honored to finalize the approval process for this contribution.
As one of the classics, this problem absolutely belongs on Codingame.
The problem statement is well-thought-out.
The wealth of test cases are sure to require the user to write a general and performant solution.
I especially like the text that says how close to the optimum you are, with a little feedback based on your performance.

Congratulations on a very nice contribution! I look forward to trying out a more advanced solution than my current greedy approach.

I liked the customized messages based on how close to the optimal/best known solution you are. Do you have a message for the case where a solver might find a solution better than your best-known solution?

I have some very small typographic suggestions:
* In the rules section: I would change "the distance ... is Euclidean - dist(a, b) ..." to "the distance ... is Euclidean: dist(a, b) ...".
* In the second tip you give, the colon shouldn't have a space before it: "... reuse your code: ...".

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good optimization puzzle

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapprove

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
great work, thanks !
Awesome work!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well done for this game!

Hi there,
Congratulations on the work behind this game, it's really interesting!

I wanted to ask you why some tests (excluding the validator) show you your % improvement but not others? 
The "Benchmarks Instance X-nxxx-kx" tests don't have a map when they're displayed. Wouldn't it be nicer to create corresponding maps to illustrate the problem?

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Rules
* Rule 1: Please add a full-stop.

* Rule 2: Please change "should" to "must".

* Please explain anything we need to know about the number of vehicles. Does it impose a limit on the total number of routes (e.g. each vehicle can only go on 1 route)?

Input
* Optional: I suggest to change the order of the first three inputs as k, c, n instead of n, k, c so that "Next n lines" immediately follows "n".

* Next n lines: Pleaes add "for the index, x and y coordinates and demand of a customer or the depot".

* Next n lines: Please format "index" (in "index=0") using the <var> tag.

Output
* Please change "tours"/"tour" to "routes"/"route" for consistency.

* Please add a full-stop to every complete sentence.

Constraints / Example
* Please be consistent in the variable names: either use lowercase letters (the same as in Input section) or uppercase letters (if so, please revise Input section).

* Please format all the variables using the <var> tag.

Example
* Please add a full-stop to every complete sentence.

* Please change "~=" to "â‰ˆ" (twice).

* Example 1 2 3; 4: Please change the last "dist(0,4)" to "dist(4,0)".

Some Tips
* The indentation seems off, compared with the section "About the Test & Validation Instances".

Stub generator (default code)
* Please change "tours"/"tour" to "routes"/"route" for consistency.

Source code
* Referee: Please change "tour" to "route" in the error message for consistency.

* The source code includes some pre-determined optimal valuesâ€¦ Are the optimal values the same for each pair of test and validator? Does that mean one who is able to get access to the source code can just hardcode those values to get a "full score" (each n corresponds to one optimal value, as n in each pair of test and validator is the same)?

Thanks.

Thanks a lot for your detailed feedback ! All of this should be fixed now.

So I like the idea of players being able to compare their results to the known optima on CVRP benchmark instances, that's why I wrote the optimal values. I changed the win messages depending on the optimality gap.
The validators are the same instances (same n, k, c) but randomized, so the optimal values are different. I added gaussian noise to the x and y coordinates, and shuffled the indices.

I'm going to change the instances though, I'm thinking about keeping maybe 3 benchmark instances, and try to make custom instances with real places on real maps. But I won't be able to prove the optimum on these instances, so they will give less detailed feedback to the players.

do these ideas sound good to you ? I'm open to any suggestions ! Thanks again

Hi Mr LeMasSon, thanks for your feedback !

I can only give the optimality gap on instances where I know the optimum. That is the case on the benchmark instances that are from the CVRPLib, but it is very difficult to prove optimality on new instances, even with the best solvers.
So for the other instances, I used the state-of-the-art metaheuristic HGS and the Hexaly solver to find the best possible solutions, but (apart from the small instances) they can't prove optimality. The win messages depend on the gap between HGS/Hexaly's solution and the player's, but it's not an actual optimality gap. Maybe I should give the gap to that solution anyway and call it something else, what do you think ?

I crafted the non-benchmark instances from geodata, but the benchmark ones don't represent real things like cities or places. So there's no obvious visualization, but I can try to think about something a bit nicer. Tell me if you have an idea for a map.
Many thanks, have fun improving your algorithm !
thanks Mr Morinho, glad you like it !
Merci mon brave LÃ©o, pas de fraude du dinosaure, c'est promis
Thanks a lot :)
glad you like it !
Thanks a lot ! Glad you like it

Thanks a lot ! There are many possible algorithms, try anything you like !
If the player improves over the best known solution, the message congratulates him and invites him to contact me so that I can update it. It would be an incredible achievement, as I used state-of-the-art CVRP solvers to find these and most of them are probably optimal already (just not proven optimal). I hope it happens anyway ;)
I corrected the typos, thanks !
Many thanks ! Have fun trying out algorithms !
I will! :)

BONJOUR J'avais un dÃ©fi sur le jeu comme un succÃ¨s et il fallait approuver ou refuser une contribution 
DÃ©solÃ© je n'est pas jouer a votre jeu je suis nul en code
Bonne journÃ©e mon brave Pierre
c'est pas nice Ã§a... Si tu veux le faire vÃ©ritablement, il y a de nombreux clash of code sympathique qui n'attende que d'Ãªtre validÃ© :)

In fact, it may be interesting to give a constant improvement estimate for all the tests. Expressing the performance gap in terms of "there is a solution that performs X% better" and then providing a message if the solution found performs better. This is still interesting.

For imaginary maps, the easiest solution would be to start out in galaxies and imagine that the company organising the tours is very high-tech. Alternatively, you could look for maps from well-known films/books that might work (e.g. Middle-earth, Narnia, etc). I don't think it's necessary for all the points to be attached to a real map element, you could add your own ;)

I'm not really convinced by these themes, I don't think they make a lot of sense for benchmark instances, and I'm not sure I can do something that looks nice (it has to be readable and there's 65 to 200 customers on these instances). I'll try to think of a better generic visualization, maybe with some icons, I'm not sure.

About the well known fictional universes : I initially wanted to make a Middle Earth instance (Farmer Maggot selling vegetables or something like that, lol) but abandoned the idea because it was harder to create the maps. In this case, I would also need the interest points of the map to match the coordinates from the instance (same number of points, same locations). so I don't think I can make something decent with these constraints anyway

I just pushed an update to display the gap on all instances. Thanks again !

Hello,

I continue to test your game...
After several tests, I think I've seen 2 "bugs", one of which is sure.

1. in the case of : Follow the Coastline (Validator)
My result is: 
- Optimality Gap: -2%
- Total Distance: 4286
And the associated sentence is: "Fantastic job! Your solution is nearly perfect, just a few steps away from optimal!" In the case of a more efficient solution, the percentage improvement becomes negative I suppose, so the associated sentence is not consistent.

2. in the case of : Example (Validateur)
In my solution found by my program, I obtained a distance of 69 but an Optimality Gap of 1%. I then manually(but generate by a script) tested all possible permutations for this case. 8 seem to me to be the optimals, but all are at 69 distance and 1%. All the other permutations had an Optimality Gap of around 20%. So I think there's a rounding error with the Optimality Gap calculation...

Thanks a lot for the testing ! What's happening here is the optimal value for validators is taken from the corresponding test case, so the resulting message is just incorrect. I didn't bother changing it, since it will not be displayed to players. The maps are also messed up for validators, since the coordinates are not the same as test cases.
Yes, you're right: can we still take into account the case where a better performing solution is found and the sentence given as a result is in line with the performance?

On instances where the optimum isn't known, the current message if you get a negative gap is the same as when the gap is 0%, something like "what an incredible solution ! it might even be optimal". (getting that would be beyond impressive, by the way)
You do get the wrong message if you have a negative optimality gap on instances where the optimum is known, but it's impossible so it would mean there is another problem. I'll add it as an edge case anyway.

Okay, as soon you update. i'll try with "Follow the Coastline (Validator)" to see.
I just have a problem with a test or two to pass and then I think I'll validate your contributions :)
Awesome ! it should be good now, although I haven't found a way to hide output for the validators. You seem to have good results already, what algorithms have you used so far ?

I used the Clarke-Wright Savings algorithm with the TSP algorithm to optimize the branches with layers of 2-opt. The problem: I still can't solve... is that my Clarke-Wright Savings algo sometimes distributes the load badly and forces me to use an extra vehicle sometimes... I think, if I don't solve this, I'll go for a solution that's clearly less efficient but will just work.
Don't worry about the validators: no one will see them. Juste during the test phase, we can see them.

oh that's a good approach. you can use local search to repair your solutions, although there are other approaches. this fits very well into a GRASP framework if you just randomize CW a little bit and iterate many times

I have wondered if I should just remove the limited fleet constraint. I think it makes the problem more interesting and more realistic, but also more difficult. Without it, it would be possible for the players to pass all the tests with only the savings or sweep heuristic. At the same time, handling additional constraints is a good learning experience. I think I'm going to look for some resources to link in the problem description, to make sure that's not too much of an obstacle.

I was just thinking about this vehicle limit. The main thing is that a limited number of vehicles greatly limits the circuit possibilities. In some cases, there is only one possible distribution of vehicles. It could be interesting to set an upper limit on the number of vehicles, or even none at all. With this paradigm shift, it would be possible to review the evaluation system. No longer focusing solely on the distance travelled, but on the total cost of delivery. For example, a truck costs X to buy and maintain and consider Y for the cost per km of road. This would allow a wider range of solutions and hypotheses? Easier to solve because we're free, but much harder to optimise!

Alright, I decided to remove the limited fleet constraint. I think implementing the savings or sweep deserves a 100% score, it's better this way and it doesn't take away from the challenge of getting the shortest possible distance.
Your idea of optimizing the fixed & variable costs tradeoff is a very good one, it's a common goal in real-life VRPs. But it makes the statement a bit more complicated, and I would like to keep the same calculations as in the CVRPLib so players can test their algorithms there as well. I also don't think it changes the solutions much : using more vehicles than necessary already penalizes the total distance, and in fact, none of the optimal values have changed on the test instances. I also don't think it's harder to optimize, so maybe it was just an unnecessary constraint.
Thanks again for your help ! You might need to change your code a little bit, sorry about that. But now your CW algorithm should pass all tests !

Yes, so everything works, even if it's far from optimal ðŸ˜…
I totally understand not wanting to implement the cost aspect in the VRPs. It would have meant a lot of other tests and forms of balancing, which I think would have been tedious for little added value in the end.

Thank you for your prompt follow-up! Just one additional comment regarding the statement:

Input
* Next n lines: Please add "space-separated" in front of "integers".

-----

I didn't read your source code in detail. I saw just one set of 20 optimal values; if those aren't the ones directly applicable to the validators, then I guess it's fine. I was just slightly worried if the source code is public and some people will just copy the optimal values for submission.

Custom instances with real places sound interesting.

Thanks again.
You may consider hiding the source code now. ðŸ˜‰
I just did, thanks :)
